history.content:
STAT 140 is not a suitable replacement for EE 126. I haven't taken EE 126, but I am currently in STAT 134. It's arguable whether STAT 134 is equivalent to EE 126, but STAT 140 is definitely not equivalent to STAT 134, let alone EE 126. STAT 140 goes into more depth than CS 70 and is valuable, just not much compared to 126.

I would consider STAT 134 if I were you, though. I would highly recommend it. EE 126 covers the same probability material as 134 (but is tougher) but then explores various applications of probability in CS (Viterbi algorithm, HMMs, auction theory), while 134 doesn't cover any applications. However in STAT 134, you go into more depth in probability material.  How can the normal approximate binomial? How can Poisson approximate binomial? How can binomial approximate hypergeometric? What are continuous joint distributions? You will learn all these topics in 134.

Looking back, I would definitely retake STAT 134 over EE 126. I'd rather learn the theory in depth, then learn applications on my own as needed. You might be more motivated by applications.

----

By Andy (aka Malayandi):

I'm a GSI for Stat 134 and work very closely (and am very good friends) with the head GSI for Stat 140. I must say I disagree quite strongly with the student answer above.

Stat 140 is not CS70-plus-plus as the student answer seems to suggest. Stat 140 covers more material than Stat 134 and I would say that it covers the material in an equally rigorous fashion, if not more so. Stat 140 was designed on top of Stat 134 by Professor Adhikari (who has taught Stat 134 countless times and is without doubt the best professor I have ever taught for or taken a course from - I have been fortunate enough to do both) so by definition almost, (as much as it hurts me to say this) Stat 140 is some sort of improvement on Stat 134 (especially for students intending to pursue a career in ML/data science).

That is perhaps more even more true of EE 126 (I have a few friends on the course staff for the course). Let me be entirely clear here. EE 126 and Stat 140 are not less theoretical, in any way, shape or form than Stat 134. EE 126 is designed as a second course in probability. If you crushed CS 70 and loved it, EE 126 is probably your best bet because there is no doubt that it is the most rigorous course of the three (and perhaps no surprise that is also the most challenging, and has the most difficult curve).

Now, if you didn't take CS 70 or found the material rather challenging but want to learn probability theory at a deeper level, Stat 134/140 is a great option. I didn't take CS 70 myself and personally felt that the probability theory in Math 55 was too soft - my apologies if that comes off disrespectful - hence why I took Stat 134 back in the day (this was well before the time of Stat 140). The material in these courses is a significant jump from CS 70 (especially the material on continuous distributions) but at the same time, isn't offered as intense a treatment as it is in EE 126 and the curve is nowhere near as difficult (if grades are a concern to you), primarily because it is intended as a first course in probability. You are not expected to have any probability background in either of these courses so I personally think it's a great place to improve your probabilistic understanding if you struggled in CS 70 but care about the material.

Stat 134 does offer an entirely theoretical approach to the material (unlike in EE 126/ Stat 140, there are no labs in this course at all) but, if you're thinking about pursuing ML/data science at a deeper level but are worried about taking EE 126, (again, it hurts me to say this but) I highly recommend taking Stat 140. Prof Adhikari and Dibya (the head GSI for 140) have done a phenomenal job building this course from scratch to offer a course that caters to students interested in probability theory and data science/ML without compromising the quality/rigor of the material in any way at all.

STAT 140 is not a suitable replacement for EE 126. I haven't taken EE 126, but I am currently in STAT 134. It's arguable whether STAT 134 is equivalent to EE 126, but STAT 140 is definitely not equivalent to STAT 134, let alone EE 126. STAT 140 goes into more depth than CS 70 and is valuable, just not much compared to 126.

I would consider STAT 134 if I were you, though. I would highly recommend it. However in STAT 134, you go into more depth in probability material.  How can the normal approximate binomial? How can Poisson approximate binomial? How can binomial approximate hypergeometric? What are continuous joint distributions? You will learn all these topics in 134.

Looking back, I would definitely retake STAT 134 over EE 126. I'd rather learn the theory in depth, then learn applications on my own as needed. You might be more motivated by applications.

You are not expected to have any probability background in either of these courses so I personally think it's a great place to improve your probabilistic understanding if you struggled in CS 70 but care about the material.

Stat 134 does offer a much more theoretical approach to the material (unlike in EE 126/ Stat 140, there are no labs in this course at all) and hence, if you're thinking about pursuing ML/data science at a deeper level but are worried about taking EE 126, (again, it hurts me to say this but) I highly recommend taking Stat 140. Prof Adhikari and Dibya (the head GSI for 140) have done a phenomenal job building this course from scratch to offer a course that caters to students interested in probability theory and data science/ML without compromising the quality/rigor of the material in any way at all.

STAT 140 is not a suitable replacement for EE 126. I haven't taken EE 126, but I am currently in STAT 134. It's arguable whether STAT 134 is equivalent to EE 126, but STAT 140 is definitely not equivalent to STAT 134, let alone EE 126. STAT 140 goes into more depth than CS 70 and is valuable, just not much compared to 126.

I would consider STAT 134 if I were you, though. I would highly recommend it. EE 126 covers the same probability material as 134 (but is tougher) but then explores various applications of probability in CS (Viterbi algorithm, HMMs, auction theory), while 134 doesn't cover any applications. However in STAT 134, you go into more depth in probability material.  How can the normal approximate binomial? How can Poisson approximate binomial? How can binomial approximate hypergeometric? What are continuous joint distributions? You will learn all these topics in 134.

Looking back, I would definitely retake STAT 134 over EE 126. I'd rather learn the theory in depth, then learn applications on my own as needed. You might be more motivated by applications.

However in STAT 134, you go into more depth in probability material.  How can the normal approximate binomial? How can Poisson approximate binomial? How can binomial approximate hypergeometric? What are continuous joint distributions? You will learn all these topics in 134.

children.subject:
Notes to some of the things anon mentioned: the normal approximation of the binomial is sometimes taught in 70, the Poisson approximation of the binomial is sometimes mentioned in 70 and more properly taught in 126, and continuous joint distributions are sometimes taught in 70 and certainly in 126. The former two are also taught in other probability-application courses like CS174.

I don't recall auction theory in 126 though, so it may depend on semester.
From the class website (prob140.org): "It won’t be offered again in 2017. The plan is to offer it in Spring 2018. I don’t know what the schedule will be after that."
Is Stat 140 offered next semester? Can't seem to find any info on it on berkeleytime.

history.content:
I am currently taking CS 189. Is it worth it to take Data C100?

Also could anyone comment on the difference between EE 126 and Stat 140 in terms of the amount of probability theory I'm going to learn? I'm primarily interested in the Data Science/ML side of things (not really signal processing). The reason I'm asking is because there are other classes at the same time as EE 126 that I was interested in (e.g CS 276, EE 127, CS 294) and was wondering if Stat 140 is a suitable replacement for 126 (given all the hype about 126).
history.subject: Could anyone comment on Data C100, Stat 140 and EE 126?
